Some philosophers have seen them as a way to access higher states of consciousness, while others have viewed them as a threat to rational thinking and moral responsibility. For example, in ancient Greece, the philosopher Plato wrote about the use of mind-altering substances in his dialogue "Phaedrus," in which he discussed the potential benefits and drawbacks of using these substances to gain access to higher knowledge.

In more recent times, philosophers such as Aldous Huxley and Terence McKenna have also written about the use of psychoactive substances and their potential for spiritual or mystical experiences. However, other philosophers such as Immanuel Kant have been more critical of the use of psychoactive substances, arguing that they can be detrimental to our ability to make rational decisions and act morally.
